data.title: Ballots cast as Catalonia votes in referendum
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) Hundreds of Catalans did manage to cast their ballot in the disputed independence referendum on Sunday, despite Spanish police trying to halt the plesbicite by smashing their way into some polling stations and firing rubber bullets at protesters outside one polling station.
Tension had been on the rise since the vote was called in early September, crystalising years of defiance by separatists in the affluent region, which contributes mightily to Spain's economy. 
As one of Spain's 17 autonomous regions, Catalonia enjoys ample rights, but key areas such as infrastructure and taxes are in the hands of Madrid. 
Separatist Catalans have long complained of contributing too much to the state while not getting enough in return.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/8a5a71d35c1854b8ca5a7c3352da01f4 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Germany celebrates 1st same-sex weddings after law change
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) Germany celebrated its first same-sex weddings on Sunday, after a new law came into force putting gay and lesbian couples on an equal legal footing with heterosexual couples.
Town halls in Berlin, Hamburg and elsewhere opened their doors to mark the event, made possible by a surprise vote in parliament three months earlier.
At Berlin's Schoeneberg district, about 60 guests and an equal number of journalists packed into the town hall's "Golden Room" to witness the marriage of Karl Kreile and his partner of 38 years, Bodo Mende.
The grooms entered the room to the popular "Wedding March" by 19th-century German composer Felix Mendelssohn, before saying their vows and signing the marriage documents to applause and cheers from the assembled guests.
Kreile, 59, and Mende, 60, had been campaigning for gay rights for decades and said they were honoured to be the first same-sex couple to marry in Germany. 
After cutting the wedding cake - featuring a rainbow flag and the words "marriage for all" - the couple planned to hold a small reception and fly to Vienna later in the week for a five-day honeymoon.
The couple first registered their partnership in 2002, when Germany introduced registered partnerships.
But those gave same-sex couples fewer rights than heterosexual couples who married.
Chancellor Angela Merkel long opposed same-sex marriages, only agreeing to a free vote in parliament on the matter in June, shortly before national elections.
The bill, which enjoyed strong public support, passed by a wide margin, with 393 lawmakers voting in favour of marriage equality and 226 - including Merkel - voting against.
Some hurdles remain, including the fact that women can't automatically recognise motherhood of a lesbian partner's child, and the software used to record marriages doesn't currently allow for two entries with the same sex.
Still, those attending Sunday's ceremony in Schoeneberg said Germany's decision to allow same-sex marriages - the 23rd country worldwide to do so - was a big step.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/4cdb0a178d0e9a40b6f268eb5c2c0e1d 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Timbuktu still recovering from heritage site damage
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) LEAD IN
Timbuktu is still recovering from the damage done by a Muslim radical to their World Heritage sites.
Despite a court ruling he must pay millions of euros in reparations, some say the damage is deeper than just structural.

STORY-LINE
Ahmadou Taghali, caretaker of the mausoleum of Sufi saint Alpha Moya in Timbuktu, works hard to clear sand from its entrance.
It was recently rebuilt, with the help of international support, after a Muslim radical led Ansar Dine militants to destroy it along with other World Heritage sites five years ago.
This summer the International Criminal Court ruled that the guilty man, Ahmad Al Faqi Al Mahdi, must pay 2.7 million euros (3.2 million US dollars) 
Residents of Timbukto have welcomed the news, but some say that although money will help with the structural damage, the moral and spiritual harm will continue.
Taghali, a descendent of Saint Alpha Moya says:
"I received the news about the reparations with mixed feelings. For me, the damage done was beyond the moral, it wasn't really just material."
He adds: "I believe that even if there is a reparations payment, it shouldn't go to individuals. It should be used to improve the protection of and the restoration of the mausoleums."
Timbuktu was famed for the reverence it gave to its saints and tourists once came here for spiritual peace.
But times have changed. Rubbish is now strewn around the mausoleum of Cheikh Sidi Ahmed Ben Amar. Locals use the site as a dump. 
This started after Al Mahdi and his pickaxe-wielding rebels reduced the mausoleum to rubble, but is still continuing today.
"Today, what grieves me the most is all this rubbish," says mausoleum guardian Mohamed Maouloud.
He adds that he's been to see people, including the Malian army general Ould Meidou and Timbuktu regional council Ould Hamadi, to see if they can fix the problem.
The sites that were attacked were built during the 15th and 16th centuries at a time when Timbuktu was considered a great centre of Islamic learning. All but one of them was on the World Heritage list.
The Netherlands based ICC found that Ahmad Al Faqi Al Mahdi had intentionally directed attacks against nine mausoleums and a mosque door in the desert city in 2012. 
Prosecutors said Al Mahdi was a member of Ansar Dine, an Islamic extremist group with links to al-Qaida which held power in northern Mali at the time. The militants were driven out after nearly a year by French forces, and those troops arrested Al Mahdi in neighbouring Niger in 2014.
The ICC said the destruction of cultural monuments like those in Timbuktu: "carries a message of terror and helplessness. (It) destroys part of humanity's shared memory and collective consciousness, and renders humanity unable to transmit its values and knowledge to future generations."
At previous hearings, Al Mahdi pleaded guilty and expressed remorse for his role in leading the destruction, urged Muslims around the world not to commit similar acts and was sentenced to nine years in prison.
Al Boukhari en Essayouti, director of Timbuktu Cultural Mission, says hearing his remorse was "a relief".


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/82fa58f3e7fe29360d890a2d8d92fb5f 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Millo: Spanish National Guard, police acted "with professionalism"
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) Spanish riot police smashed their way into polling stations to try to halt a disputed independence referendum in Catalonia on Sunday and fired rubber bullets at protesters outside a Barcelona polling station. 
Several people were injured.
The officers fired the rubber bullets while trying to clear protesters who were trying to prevent National Police cars from leaving after police confiscated ballot boxes from the voting centre. 
The Spanish government has ordered police to stop the voting process, saying it was illegal.
Catalan officials said 38 people were treated for mostly minor injuries. 
An AP photographer saw several people who had been injured during the scuffles outside Barcelona's Rius i Taule school, where some voters had cast ballots before police arrived
Catalan President Carles Puigdemont condemned the crackdown.
Enric Millo, the Spanish government's representative in the region, said police and National Guard forces acted "professionally" to enforce court orders. 
He said any attempt to claim the referendum as valid was doomed.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/bc1d926a427430f235f8af0ba9ab8270 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Pakistan's Shiite Muslims celebrate Ashoura festival
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) Thousands of Shiite Muslims across Pakistan on Sunday observed Ashoura, the holiest day on the Shiite Muslim calendar.
Ashoura is observed each year on the 10th day of Muharram, the first month of the Islamic year, to mourn the 7th century death of Imam Hussein, the grandson of Islam's Prophet Muhammad.
Authorities have stepped up security in Karachi and across the country following intelligence reports that militants could target Shiites this week.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/c2b16f96118aec43d7e958c1cc2e7d55 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Traditional weddings restored in Taiz
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) LEAD IN:
The city of Taiz is the cultural capital of Yemen, with a rich heritage that many residents are keen to preserve.
Now, an increasing number of wedding parties are reviving certain traditions as a way of keeping them alive.

STORY-LINE:
Dressed in traditional attire and smiling for the camera, these wedding guests are part of a trend sweeping the Yemeni city of Taiz.
The south-western city is renowned as the cultural capital of Yemen and as such many residents are keen to preserve their heritage.
And at this ceremony, the groom has decided to include a number of traditional elements into the day.
From traditional costumes to well-known folk music and dancing, the wedding ceremony is a feast of Yemeni culture.
A young man from the city of Taiz decided to restore the heritage of his city to the front of the scene after a long absence, through his wedding ceremony held in traditional rituals in terms of old songs, folk costumes, dancing and ancient heritage holdings.
"Today I am having my traditional wedding to revive the heritage of Taiz. We have celebrated the wedding with our own costumes, well-known in Taiz, and the usual dances known to the community which have been missed in the past," says bridegroom Abdul Nasser Al-Siddiq.
At this ceremony in At Turbah, south of Taiz, guests both young and old dance to folk music and dress in a traditional Yemeni style.
Younger generations have been learning popular folk dances to entertain their fellow guests.
Director of Taiz's Culture Office, Abdul Khalek Saif, says that many people are reviving their heritage through their wedding celebrations.
"We sing with the voice of Taiz, with its heritage, with its hats and its own costume. This is the city of Taiz, the city of life, the city of beauty, the heritage city, it will never be a city of death."
However, not everyone wants to incorporate the old traditions into their special day.
At this Taiz wedding, guests partake in the more modern custom of celebratory gunfire before dancing in the streets, late into the night.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/ab666d08134a1cc07991ed91d696b06b 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Police raid Girona polling station, people injured
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) Spanish riot police smashed their way into a polling station near the Catalan city of Girona on Sunday.
Civil Guard riot police with shields used a hammer to smash the glass of the front door of the voting centre and lock cutters to force their way in. 
Scuffles erupted outside between police and people waiting to vote at the polling centre in Sant Julia de Ramis. 
The Spanish government has ordered police to stop the voting process, saying it was illegal.
Catalan officials said 38 people were treated for mostly minor injuries across the region.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/0b1cfcb9bf2dcd528504e5085771782a 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Scenes outside Marseille station after knife attack
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) A man with a knife attacked people at the main train station in Marseille on Sunday, killing two women before soldiers fatally shot him, officials said.
French police had warned people to avoid Saint Charles train station in the southeastern city, tweeting that an operation was under way. 
Soldiers and police were seen deployed outside the station, which was evacuated.
Three police officials said one woman was stabbed to death. 
Two of the officials said the other woman's throat was slit. 
The assailant was shot dead by soldiers who were patrolling inside the station. 
The officials were speaking on condition of anonymity because they weren't authorised to speak publicly about the operation.
The Paris prosecutors' office said a counter-terrorism investigation had been opened. 
No further details were immediately given, including the motive for the attack. 
The French interior minister tweeted that he would travel to the scene.
Earlier this month, four American college students were attacked with acid at the same train station in Marseille. 
French authorities said the assailant in that attack was suffering from a mental illness.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/18c4e639ae73c46a10101084595b8884 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Marilyn Manson hurt onstage during New York show
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) MARILYN MANSON HURT ONSTAGE DURING NEW YORK SHOW
Marilyn Manson's representative says the singer was injured in a mishap on stage during a New York City performance and taken to a hospital Saturday (30 SEPT. 2017).
Variety reports that Manson was performing a cover of the Eurythmics' "Sweet Dreams (Are Made of This)" when he began to climb a podium, causing it to wobble. Manson fell backward and the prop fell on him. Soon the house and stage lights went off for several minutes and came back on with an announcer saying the show was over "due to injury."
It was not immediately clear whether any of Manson's concert dates will be postponed due to the injury.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/4f914bcb6d9e17f8589df62e5834a1bd 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Couple get married inside Bali volcano danger zone
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) Dire warnings a volcano on the Indonesia tourist island of Bali will erupt have caused tens of thousands to flee, but some who survived its last eruption in 1963 refuse to leave the danger zone, while others are pulled into it by the power of tradition.
Gede Bagus Ariksa Sudana and Yesi Fitriani, a young couple planning to legally marry in April next year, spent Sunday at Gede's village, Beluhu, inside the area declared off-limits for a steeped-in-tradition ceremony requiring prayers at a family shrine. 
Sudana, a Balinese, came from Kalimantan on Borneo where he's a policeman, and Fitriani came from her hometown Bandung in Java. 
They said they were aware of the risks. 
Dressed in handsome traditional finery, the couple were keenly aware most of Sudana's family couldn't attend the ceremony. 
In the area home to about 6,000 people, perhaps only 50 are left, said its head of adat, or tradition, who was on hand for the ceremony. 
Businesses were shuttered and the roads empty except for police patrols and the occasional villager returning to tend to animals or check on property.
They are part of a larger exodus of more than 140,000 people from the surrounds of Mount Agung since authorities raised its alert status to the highest level on September 22, though they say about half of those people have left villages in safe areas and should return home. 
Sudana's grandmother, Nengah Mungkreng, remembers Agung's last eruption in 1963, which over two major episodes in March and May of that year killed about 1,100 people. 
Government volcanologist instruments are recording hundreds of volcanic earthquakes daily as the mountain is fissured by rising magma. 
A dramatic escalation in that type of earthquake was the basis for officials to put the volcano on high alert and warn an eruption was possible anytime. 
Gede Windu, a villager who spends his days tending goats in a dried out river bed that the mountain looms over, said he was about seven years old when Agung erupted in 1963.
After the eruption, Windu said he and his family lived in an evacuee camp for about eight months and returned to their village after the government stopped distributing food.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/5fc00f37e762759bf67ca2b9ad03fbc8 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

Government volcanologist instruments are recording hundreds of volcanic earthquakes daily as the mountain is fissured by rising magma. 
A dramatic escalation in that type of earthquake was the basis for officials to put the volcano on high alert and warn an eruption was possible anytime. 
Gede Windu, a villager who spends his days tending goats in a dried out river bed that the mountain looms over, said he was about seven years old when Agung erupted in 1963.
After the eruption, Windu said he and his family lived in an evacuee camp for about eight months and returned to their village after the government stopped distributing food.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/5fc00f37e762759bf67ca2b9ad03fbc8 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork
asset.author: AP Archive

data.title: Spain deputy PM: Police action proportional and firm
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) Spain's deputy prime minister on Sunday said Spanish police have intervened with "firmness and proportionality" against the Catalan vote on secession.
Soraya Saenz de Santamaria said authorities acted in a professional and proportional way, and they weren't going after voters, but referendum material.
She accused the Catalan government which is trying to hold the referendum of behaving irresponsibly.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/af1a4c3d27563040fb7551fd5ac3293d 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Scenes at Marseille train station amid security alert
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) French police on Sunday warned people to avoid Marseille's main train station amid reports of a knife attack.
Saint Charles train station was evacuated and police on their official Twitter account said an operation was under way.
No other details were immediately available.
French television station BFM TV reported at least one person had been stabbed and that the assailant had been shot dead.
The interior minister tweeted he was travelling to the scene of the attack.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/6037a17c27f3a05c8f2e21ce3da0126d 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Vietnam prepares for moon festival with lantern parade
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) A colourful lantern parade lit up the streets of Tuyen Quang in northern Vietnam on Sunday ahead of the popular Mid-Autumn, or Moon Festival. 
The lanterns were inspired by characters of folklore and modern figures, from common household animals to Vietnam's endangered red-crowned cranes. 
The festival is held on the full moon of the eighth month of the lunar calendar, when the moon is at its fullest and brightest.
Traditionally, the festival was held to honour the moon in the hope of ensuring a successful harvest


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/b5152031e70b99c5bf71788bbc6f9162 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Festival celebrates ancient Queen
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) LEAD IN:
Alexandria has held a special event to celebrate the ancient leader Cleopatra.
Actors paraded through the streets to bring attention to the sunken palace of Cleopatra which lies on the seabed of the city's harbour.

STORY-LINE:
Dressed in the costumes of their ancient ancestors, Egyptians parade through the streets of Alexandria.
Actors are playing the soldiers and handmaids of Queen Cleopatra, the last ruler of the Ptolemaic dynasty.
The legendary leader emerges, pulled past the crowds on a golden throne by her soldiers.
The event has been named 'Cleopatra's Dream' and it has taken a lot of effort to make sure this huge procession works like clockwork.
Actor Mahmoud Abd Elaziz plays the soldiers' commander.
"We did 17 rehearsals: ten in the studios and seven outdoors. It was not easy," he says.
The parade passes along the Alexandria Corniche, from the Citadel of Qaitbay towards the diving centre at the Eastern Port.
This event is being held to draw attention to the sunken city of Cleopatra in the sea around Alexandria. 
Hundreds of lost antiquities have been found in Alexandria's coastal waters in recent years. In 2015, over 200 treasures from Ancient Egyptian times were discovered.
It adds to the country's rich history - something the actors have studied closely for their roles.
"We studied the things they used like jewellery and colours. For example the colour blue symbolises the sky, and they were always aiming for eternal life," says Shery Kamal, who plays a maid.
"We also studied other things like make-up and the importance of the scarab."
The celebration comes hot on the heels of World Tourism Day and has been organised in coordination with the Ministry of Tourism and the Tourism Promotion Authority.
Since the uprising that toppled former president Hosni Mubarak in 2011, Egypt's tourism industry has taken a heavy toll.
In 2016, in an attempt to bring back foreign visitors, the country's Ministry of Antiquities announced a plan to establish what it dubbed the world's first underwater museum to showcase the submerged relics of Alexandria's ancient treasures.
The plan has not yet been carried out, but the director of today's show hopes events like this might help attract more visitors.
"We have created a street carnival that represents the dream of Cleopatra in order to activate tourism. We believe that there is nothing better than art to stimulate tourism," says Fady Nour.
Cleopatra boards her golden boat and heads out into the sea.
The ancient leader's palace and other buildings and monuments lie strewn on the seabed in the harbour of Alexandria, the second largest city of Egypt. 
Since 1994, archaeologists have been exploring the ruins, one of the richest underwater excavations in the Mediterranean, discovering around 6,000 artefacts. 
Perhaps this watery treasure trove could be the secret to bringing tourists back to the city.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/77d36ca8aa111070f3cc89cfd0ee906f 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

asset.author: AP Archive

data.title: Barcelona defender Pique on referendum vote
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) Football player for FC Barcelona and the Spanish national team Gerard Pique couldn't hold back tears as he talked about the incidents in Catalonia on Sunday. 
Spanish riot police smashed their way into polling stations across Catalonia to try and stop Sunday's referendum, sometimes beating voters. 
Catalonia's health services say 761 people were injured by police on Sunday, with two of them in serious condition.
Pique said he was proud of the Catalan people and said that he was ready to quit the Spanish national team if anyone from the football federation thought he was "a problem" or "an annoyance".
However, Pique said he thought he could stay in the national team, because "there are a lot of people in Spain who disapprove of these events that happened in Catalonia and who believe in democracy."


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/e7a7bcf6e134f0b9a1a780b90ddf08c8 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Mexico quake toll death toll rises to 361
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) The death toll from Mexico's magnitude 7.1 earthquake rose to 361 Sunday after another casualty was confirmed in the capital. 
National Civil Defense chief Luis Felipe Puente reported on Twitter that the dead include 220 people killed in Mexico City by the Sept. 19 quake. The rest were in Morelos, Puebla and three other states.
The toll has continued to climb gradually nearly two weeks after the earthquake as bodies keep being pulled from the rubble - though nearly all the collapse sites have been cleared by now in Mexico City.
Search efforts continue at the site of a collapsed seven-story office building in a central neighborhood of the capital, where 41 bodies have been recovered. 
Mayor Miguel Angel Mancera said Sunday that eight people are still believed to be missing inside the wreckage of the office building, one of 38 Mexico City buildings that collapsed in the quake.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/54b1daf0e17db86aad059362fd09ef0f 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Timbuktu still recovering from heritage site damage
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) LEAD IN
Timbuktu is still recovering from the damage done by a Muslim radical to their World Heritage sites.
Despite a court ruling he must pay millions of euros in reparations, some say the damage is deeper than just structural.

STORY-LINE
Ahmadou Taghali, caretaker of the mausoleum of Sufi saint Alpha Moya in Timbuktu, works hard to clear sand from its entrance.
It was recently rebuilt, with the help of international support, after a Muslim radical led Ansar Dine militants to destroy it along with other World Heritage sites five years ago.
This summer the International Criminal Court ruled that the guilty man, Ahmad Al Faqi Al Mahdi, must pay 2.7 million euros (3.2 million US dollars) 
Residents of Timbukto have welcomed the news, but some say that although money will help with the structural damage, the moral and spiritual harm will continue.
Taghali, a descendent of Saint Alpha Moya says:
"I received the news about the reparations with mixed feelings. For me, the damage done was beyond the moral, it wasn't really just material."
He adds: "I believe that even if there is a reparations payment, it shouldn't go to individuals. It should be used to improve the protection of and the restoration of the mausoleums."
Timbuktu was famed for the reverence it gave to its saints and tourists once came here for spiritual peace.
But times have changed. Rubbish is now strewn around the mausoleum of Cheikh Sidi Ahmed Ben Amar. Locals use the site as a dump. 
This started after Al Mahdi and his pickaxe-wielding rebels reduced the mausoleum to rubble, but is still continuing today.
"Today, what grieves me the most is all this rubbish," says mausoleum guardian Mohamed Maouloud.
He adds that he's been to see people, including the Malian army general Ould Meidou and Timbuktu regional council Ould Hamadi, to see if they can fix the problem.
The sites that were attacked were built during the 15th and 16th centuries at a time when Timbuktu was considered a great centre of Islamic learning. All but one of them was on the World Heritage list.
The Netherlands based ICC found that Ahmad Al Faqi Al Mahdi had intentionally directed attacks against nine mausoleums and a mosque door in the desert city in 2012. 
Prosecutors said Al Mahdi was a member of Ansar Dine, an Islamic extremist group with links to al-Qaida which held power in northern Mali at the time. The militants were driven out after nearly a year by French forces, and those troops arrested Al Mahdi in neighbouring Niger in 2014.
The ICC said the destruction of cultural monuments like those in Timbuktu: "carries a message of terror and helplessness. (It) destroys part of humanity's shared memory and collective consciousness, and renders humanity unable to transmit its values and knowledge to future generations."
At previous hearings, Al Mahdi pleaded guilty and expressed remorse for his role in leading the destruction, urged Muslims around the world not to commit similar acts and was sentenced to nine years in prison.
Al Boukhari en Essayouti, director of Timbuktu Cultural Mission, says hearing his remorse was "a relief".


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/82fa58f3e7fe29360d890a2d8d92fb5f 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: At least 2 dead after Las Vegas concert shooting
data.description:
(2 Oct 2017) A Las Vegas hospital says at least two people are dead and dozens wounded after a shooting late on Sunday at a music festival on the Las Vegas Strip.
A University Medical Center spokeswoman said 26 people were admitted to the hospital. She says, of those, at least two have died, 12 are in critical condition and the rest are being evaluated.
Dozens of patrol vehicles descended on the Strip after authorities received reports of an active shooter near the Route 91 Harvest Festival.
Sergeant Jeff Clark of the Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department, urged people to steer clear of the area.
Authorities shut down part of the Las Vegas Strip and Interstate 15.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/c31d94a0befcbfa0b83a838a5a20ab93 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

data.title: Pakistan's Shiite Muslims celebrate Ashoura festival
data.description:
(1 Oct 2017) Thousands of Shiite Muslims across Pakistan on Sunday observed Ashoura, the holiest day on the Shiite Muslim calendar.
Ashoura is observed each year on the 10th day of Muharram, the first month of the Islamic year, to mourn the 7th century death of Imam Hussein, the grandson of Islam's Prophet Muhammad.
Authorities have stepped up security in Karachi and across the country following intelligence reports that militants could target Shiites this week.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/c2b16f96118aec43d7e958c1cc2e7d55 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork
